Angelina Jolie's film as a director is a gorgeously shot and hardhitting old-school war drama - but still somehow fails to get under its subject's skin.
If you go down to the woods today... you'll find A-listers dressed like 'Game of Thrones' extras belting out showtunes.
No one watches Gone with the Wind for historical accuracy. What keeps us coming back is four-hours of epic romance in gorgeous Technicolor.
As plastic as the films it attempts to lampoon.
A movie about the hard-to-reach interior landscapes inside all of us -- rushing currents of blood, jostling crowds of sperm, electrified neurons in the brain.
There are bad movies, there are disappointing movies, and then there's Pootie Tang, a movie so incompetent, it almost defies description.
An abstract, symbolic title is perfect for such an abstract, symbolic movie.
A.I.'s success rests entirely on the narrow shoulders of Haley Joel Osment, and he is astonishing - the finest child actor since Jodi Foster.
Herz's genius lies in his ability to push beyond the obvious joke into nightmarish territory, until the audience is doubled over with horrified laughter.
The good news is that the film is about as careful an adaptation as can be imagined, one that takes next to no liberties with the original text.
movie_title: Harry Potter and the Sorcerer's Stone (2001)

movie_review_blurb: Bears about as much resemblance to the experiences of most battered women as Spider-Man does to the experiences of most teenagers.
Finds a way to tell a simple story, perhaps the simplest story of all, in a way that seems compelling and even original.
A riot of sterility, with planetscape after stunning planetscape swallowing up its characters and their petty concerns.
movie_title: Star Wars: Episode II - Attack of the Clones (2002)

movie_review_blurb: By avoiding the syrup, About a Boy also avoids the banality of movies like As Good as it Gets.
A turgid little history lesson, humourless and dull.
The film doesn't really care about the thousands of Americans who die hideously, it cares about how Ryan meets his future wife and makes his start at the CIA.
It's a top-notch work with a lot more humour than most Kurosawa films.
Remember the Titans works just fine.
A hideous, confusing spectacle, one that may well put the nail in the coffin of any future Rice adaptations.
Sena is a devotee of what should be called the Maxim school of filmmaking, and his movies are all about the getting the goods: fast cars, expensive electronics, swish houses, beautiful babes.
The film has been attractively packaged, and if -- like many fans -- you'd pay to watch Clint read a menu, then you'll find Space Cowboys an enjoyable time warp back to the summer of '98.
Running out of stuff to make the characters do, Di Pego is reduced to having them make speeches.
It's not quite enough of a treat to recommend to child-free adults, but grownups with kids have nothing to fear from this good-hearted, badassed comedy.
Acting from the three leads is solid, and director Mimi Leder manages to make their problems meaningful, despite the heavy we-can-change- the-world message.
Not quite strong enough for a champion status, Best in Show still makes a pretty solid case for runner-up.
Starts out intelligently, only to fall apart during its last act.
Amid this excess of action set pieces and no fewer than six musical numbers, the snappy chemistry between Kline and Branagh is reduced to a sideshow, when it should have been the main event.
The 50-foot waves and screaming winds (a blend of Industrial Light & Magic effects and the real-life Hurricane Floyd, which arrived during filming) are exceptionally terrifying.
Exists only to provide middle-class, middle-brow entertainment.
Though Superman has aged more gracefully than many '70s sci-fi films, the film's drawn-out first act may make viewers long for the more modern wham-blam style of comic-book movies.

Though the script is remarkably faithful to Jennifer Egan's novel, it relies too heavily on voice-over to move the plot along, preferring to baldly inform the audience of developments than letting us figure them out for ourselves.
May be opulent, but it's not deep.
Disaster should have been a foregone conclusion.
Kirikou's depiction of Africa and Africans is dignified, not Disneyfied, and though that may not help the film at the box office, it does make for a welcome change.
Contains a few genuine surprises, and demands that audiences remain attentive.
Dialogue-heavy and too cerebral for its own good -- or, at any rate, too cerebral for its racy subject matter.
Quote not available.
The performances from the ensemble cast are extremely strong, especially from Bentley and Jovovich, but somehow their feelings end up being muffled.
The film's success is due almost entirely to the scriptwriting team of David Mamet and Steven Zaillian, who smooth out the rougher edges of Thomas Harris' novel and actually improve the story.
Part of the long, noble tradition (at least since the '90s) of talky, ensemble-driven American indies.
Goldberg -- a secular Jew who grew up in Jerusalem -- appears genuinely interested in what the youngsters have to say, and out of their conversations comes an even-handed portrait of a troubled land.
Provides a magnificent greatest-hits compilation of scenes from the life of the artist, but fails to invest them with sufficient meaning.
Ricci is perfectly cast, and seems to relish her character's blend of cruelty and cluelessness.
As muted and still as a Vermeer painting, Girl With a Pearl Earring has atmosphere to burn and a near-total action vacuum.

While the hostage-taking story alone is compelling drama, Brazilian documentarian José Padilha pushes the story further, making a compelling case that the incident was an inevitable result of a city that treats street kids as vermin.
Polley wipes herself of all intelligence and beauty for the role, and almost all emotion; her lack of affect is both frustrating and somehow fitting.
Hamer is gifted with both a sly wit and a rich visual vocabulary.
Law and Kidman are the stars, but it's the secondary characters that the audience will connect with and remember, especially Ruby.
Not the last word on the subject by any means, but it is a solid entry into the canon that sensibly resists beatification or crucifixion of the Ariel poet.
Despite the film's predictability, there's something in the film that makes you want to root for the bad guy.
There's simply too much here to digest.
Feigns compassion for the mentally challenged, but treats Radio as a pet, a toy, a prop.
A well-paced horror whose slick, exhilarating action sequences are a significant improvement over the original.
Everything about this movie is painfully stock.

The idea that our culture is dumbing down is nothing new, but fortunately Stupidity skips the predictable finger-wagging at our collective idiocy in favour of a more interesting, academic study of stupidity.
The problem is the subject matter: a cozy ode to fatherhood with a maudlin audacity that would make Dickens blush.
An exercise in ponderous gloom and doom.
This is as respectful a film as Byatt fans could hope for, though lovers of the book may wonder why it's necessary.
Considered less as a piece of entertainment and more as an argument constructed to further a feminist agenda, the film is hugely impressive.
This film would have been better with a lot more gospel and a lot less Gooding.
Close enough to Guy Ritchie's Lock, Stock and Two Smoking Barrels to make no difference, Nicotina delivers the predictable in a blur of phone calls, gunshots and lightning-fast editing.
A compelling and ultimately positive portrait of teenagers.
Ejiofor lends the film a calm intelligence, though his character is almost too moral to be believed.
Drowning's too good for this sucker.
Fails to convince the audience that these brats will ever be anything more than losers.
The creaking, rusty ship makes a fine backdrop, but the ghosts' haunting is routine.
It generates a paltry amount of drama.
For a film about two mismatched buddies, Crystal and De Niro share little screen time and even less chemistry.
The story is naturally poignant, but first-time screenwriter Paul Pender overloads it with sugary bits of business.
Pfeiffer is not an actress with much sense of mystery, so it's hard to swallow her dangerous mommy-mystique shtick.
The film is completely predictable, yet two questions remain: why would Becky want to hook up with a loser like Paul, and what is the talented Stiles doing in this movie?
A potent illustration of the profound impact words and ideas can have, even across decades and disparate milieux.
Like song lyrics that look clunky when written on the page, lines from the book die a thousand deaths when they come out of the mouths of the actors.
Gordon and Co. slobber all over themselves at how quaint and wonderful the British are, producing an effect that is strongly, cheesily American.
As a Rugrats neophyte, I found it hard to understand what makes them so beloved: their voices are shrill and charmless, and so much of the humour springs from grating babytalk.
It would be almost likeable if it weren't for the contradictions that rip the guts out of the set-up.
A turgid, pretentious piece of work that may have played well on the page, but is too heavy and slow-moving to work on the big screen.
Like all infomercials, Ayurveda: Art of Being is heavy on testimonials and light on statistics.
Journalists don't usually get much respect at the movies, but Veronica Guerin is successful in its straight-up retelling of the true story of a journalist who turned into a modern-day martyr.
Gilbert is a must watch for budding comedians just as it is for people who want to know more about a rather mysterious man.
... Bateman proves his direction as remarkable at the very least, giving the drama and comedy film a suspenseful and skeptically ominous feeling ...
The film was an exciting display of visual cues that reminds one of Life of Pi when digital filmmaking really took off.
If you liked Anchorman, you'll probably find things to like about The Other Guys, but it's not a classic even for rabid Ferrell enthusiasts.
A sparse, engaging film perhaps easier to respect than love, but by any measure hugely compelling.
If you're looking for a fun date movie with realistic characters you can genuinely root for, see this film. Best rom-com of the year? Quite likely.
Joaquin Phoenix gives the performance of a lifetime. Funny, tragic, compulsive and utterly one of a kind, you must see this film.
A startlingly excellent dark comedy about the power of positive posthumous PR. One of 2010's must-see movies.

Compulsive entertainment with an intelligent script that knows exactly how to maximise its cat-and-mouse tensions, slyly inviting us to appreciate and anticipate the inventive contributions of the cat quite as much as the mouse.
Mesmeric in the way that staring at a tank of tropical fish for a couple of hours is mesmeric. Still, just the ticket if you're high, recovering from major surgery or are a cat.
movie_title: Uncle Boonmee Who Can Recall His Past Lives (2011)

movie_review_blurb: A lumbering beast that's stately where it should be nimble. Best stick with the original film.
Let's all go play baseball in the park with some ghosts, rather than wasting our time watching this silly, silly film.
Another proud entry in the Loud Noises Are Scary sub-genre of horror that fails to engage on anything more than the silliest level. You're better off sticking with Britain's Most Haunted.
A light, lovingly handled tale about the difficulties of staying in love.
Pure tosh. On absolutely no account pay money to see this film. Wait until it's given away free with a magazine and start at around the forty minute mark.

A rare and vital film that nails the concerns of privileged post-adolescence in the first few years of the 21st century, and, more universally, draws out eternal themes of truth, subjectivity and envy with an effortless elegance.
Another week, another Jennifer Aniston rom-com. This one's passable, but saddled with a problematic central plot device.
Welcome to the one of the best fourth parts of a horror franchise ever made.
The main pleasure in The Girl Who Played With Fire is in spending more time with the characters who made such a vivid impression in The Girl With The Dragon Tattoo.
movie_title: The Girl Who Played with Fire (Flickan som lekte med elden) (2010)

movie_review_blurb: Dear me, but director Tony Scott is a wily fox.
If you played classical music to your unborn child in the hopes of spawning a genius, this one's for you.
A drama that stands or falls by the strength of its lead. Fortunately, that lead is Kristin Scott Thomas, and she's superb.
There is much about The Rebound that does not work, but you can't help giving it some credit for attempting to roam slightly outside the scope of most rom-coms, even if it can't entirely pull it off.
How can you not find a space in your heart for a 21st century villain saddled with the name Julien?
Now here's a film there's absolutely no excuse for.
movie_title: Cats & Dogs: The Revenge of Kitty Galore (2010)

movie_review_blurb: Really, how can you not love Joan Jett weeing on a guitar then slipping over in her own piss? It's Frank Spencer meets Sid Vicious.
Knight And Day is to cinema what Andre The Giant was to acting.
Hilarious, and at just 85 minutes long, never outstays its welcome.
Pre-dating even early genre landmarks Nosferatu (1922) and Metropolis (1926) by some distance, Robert Wiene's silent film is both influential and one of a kind.
movie_title: The Cabinet of Dr. Caligari (Das Cabinet des Dr. Caligari) (1920)

movie_review_blurb: A deceptively simple and humorous tale with wonderfully nasty flashes of violence that feel entirely real.
We can understand the need to have a support group for elderly action heroes who want to relive the glory years. But did they have to release it as a film? Unnecessary.
Daft, but entertaining enough while it lasts, and it's oddly fun to see that venerable villainess, the Cold War, showing the young upstarts how it's done.
Something that helps distinguish The Last Exorcism is the care with which it sets out its stall.
This proves you don't necessarily need money when you've got an honest, striking script.
An embarrassing and unhappy compromise between the bland, lacklustre characterisation of The Phantom Menace and the achingly naff would-be cool of The Matrix sequels.
As magical as ever.
movie_title: Big Mommas: Like Father, Like Son (2011)

movie_review_blurb: A mess, but one of those messes where it's at least fun to debate the different ways in which it got it so wrong and could have been great.
Not an easy journey for the characters or their audience, Reichardt's film demands respect for its sheer bloody-minded determination to leave its own questions frustratingly up for debate.
Even if you have your reservations about the Disneyfication of Winnie The Pooh, you should consider giving this charming film a whirl.
There are funny lewd, crude comedies, and there are lame lewd, crude comedies. Regrettably, this is the second type.
Bright, breezy, entertaining and essentially forgettable, Rio is pretty much everything you would hope for in a children's film, no more, no less.
An arresting snow-bound oddity concerning a character you can't care for and yet feel compelled to watch.
Gripping for the duration, and pacier than you might expect from a film where the same eight minutes play out repeatedly...
This Easter, celebrate with a slice of rabbit pie at home while avoiding this film.
Proves that while masturbating over your cast may not make you blind, it can impair directorial vision.
A film that's actually about something real? Incredible, but true.
Isn't exactly groundbreaking stuff, but if you're looking for Friday night thrills, The Resident should do the job.
It's a little like if Men In Black was recast with an army of John Majors, and about as sexy as that sounds.
Quantum string theory, it ain't. But it's passable enough if you just fancy gawping at some glossy leads for a bit.
Excellent Aussie crime drama thoroughly deserving of its across-the-board rave reviews. We repeat: go and see it.
A taut thriller with a nasty streak, you may not want to take these characters home for tea and cakes, but you'll want to find out what happens to them.
Genre fans are advised to steer clear.
The Rite covers similar thematic ground to that trodden recently by the more effective and fun The Last Exorcism.
The juicy, toxic and unhealthy cinema equivalent of the biggest, tastiest and least nutritional burger you've ever wolfed down in a moment of heedless gluttony.
Yes, it bears absolutely no resemblance to the historical art of burlesque, but that's like complaining Jurassic Park didn't have enough palaeontology in it.
Occasionally tense middlebrow thriller that lacks both the set pieces needed to really ramp up the tension and the subtlety to make you care much about the characters.
A rarely cheery but carefully crafted look at flawed and all-too human behaviour, worth seeing for Michelle Williams and Ryan Gosling's sincere, intelligent performances.
Commendable without being especially electrifying, Conviction is held together by committed performances, despite a relative lack of flair in other departments.
Equal parts amusing and tedious - but not in any sense the disaster some have called it.
Doesn't appear to set out to eroticise rape, but equally doesn't care if eroticising rape is a by-product of its aim to provoke an emotive reaction - any reaction - in viewers
With some dreadfully unfunny scenes sprinkled with occasional comic highlights mainly involving Owen Wilson, this is barely passable stuff.
Don't get mad, get sexy! If this doesn't get the kids interested in ballet, nothing will.
Do yourself and the normally appealing Giamatti a favour and watch Sideways again instead.
A Little Bit Of Heaven makes you ask some really big questions. The biggest is why anyone involved in this film thought any of it was a good idea.
Predictable, but solid enough.
A push-me-pull-you film straining in all sorts of different directions and getting nowhere.
Solid, classy entertainment with something for practically everyone, from casual film fans to Coen brothers obsessives.
The ideal date movie if your tactic is to yawn your inamorata into bed - even the most unremarkable sex would be more diverting.

Seemingly well-intentioned and inoffensive - but there are so many other films that do this sort of thing faster, better and with more jokes, including a couple from writer-director James L Brook's own back catalogue.
Can a summer blockbuster with a multi-million dollar budget really be this smart, moving and intellectually thrilling? Pinch yourselves, we could still be dreaming.
Not a film where viewers will learn an awful lot, this is aimed fair and square at entertaining children and perhaps their parents' inner children. In this aim, it succeeds.

Better than the first two instalments, but not likely to endear itself to detractors, Eclipse is all about the trashy topless wolves, dreamy abstinent vampires and doomy teenaged longing, with Hard Candy director David Slade making the most of a marginall
Welcome to the Pussycat Dolls Do Italy. If we wanted to see a middle-aged has-been drooling over an Ann Summers live show, we'd stalk Peter Stringfellow.
The groundbreaking FX work is worth the price of admission alone, while the rollicking adventure story should find fans from eight to 80.
Don't go expecting joyous escapism, but if you're interested in seeing melancholic auteur filmmaking, complete with a lush soundtrack... you won't see a more compelling film this year.
It's a film, Jim, but not as we know it: a meandering bad trip through a gorgeously shot Spain that's really only accessible to tenacious Jarmusch enthusiasts.
Diverting and well made with solid performances, but Carriers adds nothing new.

The Girlfriend Experience is no date movie: Soderbergh offers a snappily paced but tonally bleak snapshot of an alienated young woman who has ridden the new culture of personal branding to its psychological and physical limits.

Think very carefully before you attempt to unlock the mysteries of The Box. There is no going back, you cannot undo your decision, you will never get back those 115 minutes, and by the horrifying end, those same 115 minutes will feel like a life sentence.

For those who like Charlie Kaufman on paper but occasionally find themselves a little tested by his self-conscious meanderings in practice, the hilarious Cold Souls is a pleasingly tight and subtle execution of an eye-opening concept.
Jennifer's Body has more to say about the dynamics of teenaged female friendship, sexual power games and the trials of adolescence than many a more self-consciously worthy film.
This is a film that belongs to the noble heritage of beery DVD nights with a takeaway and themed movie double bill.
Coffin Rock stands or falls entirely by your reaction to these people - it's not horror, it's a melodramatic thriller, and seen from this perspective, it works nicely.

A eulogy, a polemic, an intriguing mess: Dr Parnassus is ultimately more worth your time than many a polished creation, and it's a must for Terry Gilliam completists, but this time out he delivers a feast for the eyes more than he satisfies intellectually
Tony Jaa is a martial arts star. Is he a director? No. The dull plotting and predictable characters in Ong Bak: The Beginning all but overwhelms Jaa doing what he does best, which is fighting.
Pandorum's insistence on action sequence after action sequence, reveal after reveal, tension upon tension deadens the effect any of it might have had in a more gracefully developed narrative.

Hugh, what a stinker! Mediocre sit-com humour doesn't help an unoriginal premise and a star pairing with less believable chemistry than a pebble and another slightly smaller pebble. Where's a straight-to-video distributor when you need one?
movie_title: Did You Hear About the Morgans? (2009)

movie_review_blurb: A little comedy that dares to think big, Ricky Gervais makes the leap to Hollywood comedy lead with aplomb in a sweet film that will give you a whole new appreciation of the power of telling porkies.
Makes its point very effectively in the first 10 minutes and has subsequent difficulties convincing as a full-length narrative feature; a documentary treatment could have been more illuminating.
movie_title: BirdWatchers - La terra degli uomini rossi (2008)

movie_review_blurb: A funny, lip-smacking 3D adventure that looks good enough to eat and isn't afraid to tickle your brainy bits too.
movie_title: Cloudy With a Chance of Meatballs (2009)

movie_review_blurb: A kind of Canadian World War I version of Pearl Harbor recast with TV actors and made on a tenth of the budget - yet for all that more endearing than Pearl Harbour.
Sin Nombre is a spry, humane account of the hardships encountered on the Mexican immigration trail, whose violence never feels exploitative, for all that it may be hard to watch. Highly recommended.
A creepy premise is undermined by wilfully flashy direction as a fine cast struggle bravely to inject credibility into a tale of vanishing nuns and burning treehouses.
Technically accomplished holiday fun to while away a wet afternoon with the sprogs, G-Force is exciting while it lasts, but about as memorable as the bucket of over-priced popcorn.

An admirably understated central performance from Sophie Okenedo, supported by a fine cast, gives a human face to this true-life race relations drama, which never over-simplifies in favour of easy emotional wins.

Too deep into the saga to win over any Potter virgins, this is payback for those who've followed the series from the start, with some of what was good about the books making a comfortable transition to screen.
movie_title: Harry Potter and the Half-Blood Prince (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Ultimately a romp, albeit one with some entertaining quirks and a strange melancholy undertow, we shouldn't make overly high-falutin' claims for Ichi, but fans of balletic fight scenes should get a kick out of some good-looking sequences.

Delivering an emotional punch to the gut in the final reel, this engaging account of an under-reported tragedy will remind you how cinema can still rise to the occasion and go beyond the empty bangs and flashes of tent pole releases.

Quite simply one of the more embarrassing films we've ever seen, Beyond The Fire is bad in a way that only a film aspiring to deal with a serious, sensitive subject and falling flat on its face can be.
Great if you're already versed in the work of the figures chatting happily away here, more of an archive curio if you're not.
movie_title: Painters Painting - The New York Art Scene: 1940-70 (1972)

movie_review_blurb: Marion Cajori makes a brave attempt to grapple with a subject who resists explanation; while she may not always succeed, the journey is frequently illuminating.
movie_title: Louise Bourgeois: The Spider, the Mistress and the Tangerine (2008)

movie_review_blurb: One for the none too discerning youngster.

An attractive slice of glossy dystopian sci-fi shenanigans from the team behind Terminator 3 sees Bruce Willis reprising the one-cop-against-the-system role that he could by now play in his sleep. Or even via a remote controlled robotic surrogate.
Director Stuart Hazeldine makes the most of a small budget and modest cast in a solidly put together watch-it-once thriller that's all about the process of solving the puzzle at its heart.
It's a nice set-up, but the supporting cast are retreads of characters we've seen many times from Disney throughout the ages, and their wisecracks won't measure up for a grown-up crowd.
Unsuccessful but fascinating and often entertaining attempt from Martin Scorsese to wrangle with baroque pulp fiction - by turns compelling, hysterical and silly.
It would be kindest to ignore Tetro.
There's no real narrative, just three folk in latex OAP masks snorting and cackling through a series of often noctural adventures with wheelchairs, hookers and undead-looking street poet types.
Wild Target is a remake of a French farce, and it shows.
This is a small film, which, if you're open to it, will draw you into the lives of people you quickly forget are fictional.
Unlike many of 2010's comedies so far, hilarity does indeed ensue.
Cat lovers: this is not your film - a nasty fate awaits the household moggy. Alas, poor Tiddles.
Leading man Will Forte will make you pine for the graceful savoir faire of a Jack Black or an Adam Sandler.
Certainly no worse - faint praise alert - than your average sitcom.
See this film for uniformly excellent performances and a beguiling aesthetic, but approach with caution if Manhattan-era Woody Allen drives you up the wall.
An unashamedly mushy concoction, Letters To Juliet is the cinematic equivalent of a Barbara Cartland novel, aimed at mainstream romance fans aged anywhere between 13 and 113.
The Killer Inside Me undoubtedly touches upon compelling subjects, but having done so, doesn't appear to know quite what to do next.
Hard to imagine a reason to see this at the cinema; its natural home is a half-arsed DVD rental accompanied by pizza and the feeling that you owe it to yourself to do better.
Not that Sex And The City has ever been lauded for its subtlety and grace, but this really is the closest to a Carry On film that the franchise has come so far.
Decent performances from the actors involved can't disguise the fact that this is a hollow bauble. But if you're in the mood for cinematic junk food, you might get a kick out of it.
Formulaic family entertainment starring a wrestler-turned-actor as a hockey-player-turned-tooth fairy. Visual gags and wackiness ensue.
Cage and Herzog have created a superbly memorable lead character, and if the plot itself is curiously unmemorable, certain images will stay with you to the grave...
movie_title: Bad Lieutenant: Port of Call New Orleans (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Surprisingly convoluted for a film that is at its finest when delivering visceral wham-bam battle sequences.
It's the comic role of a lifetime for Jim Carrey, who apparently worked for union rates in order to help the film get made.
It's as hard to root for somebody who views his relationships through this egocentric prism as you would expect.
[A] boring, overlong mess.
[A] strong contender for thriller of the year.
movie_title: The Girl with the Dragon Tattoo (2009)

movie_review_blurb: If you've seen the trailer, you've seen the best bits, and if you've seen Cloverfield, you've seen the Kraken.
Robert Pattinson proves he can do more than fanged heartthrob, but while the film should sate his legion fans til their next Twilight fix, there's not a lot here for the rest of us.
It's not as much sheer fun as Predator, but then again, what is?
Stylishly cinematic ode to the dreams of youth and the will to escape the shackles that so relentlessly conspire to trap us in everything that is most limiting about our lives

A film that dares contemplate some huge themes, Agora shines light on a charming and neglected historical figure, but gets a little lost in trying to do too much aside from what ought to be its main focus.
What have the Romans ever done for us? Raped and pillaged mostly, according to a film that also appears to want us to root for them. Bizarre
Valhalla Rising may test your patience, but offers images unlike anything else you're likely to see this year.
One of the most surprising, entertaining and eccentric films released this year.
If you've seen the trailer, you've seen the best bits.
It's a film that raises the larger question of why we're seeing vehicles for high profile female stars, written by women, that nevertheless manage to be intensely patronising towards women.
Though Repo Man is unmistakably a mess, it must be admitted that it contains some defiantly silly and entertaining moments
A thrilling, funny and moving human drama for pretty much everyone, not just biking enthusiasts.
Let's not waste each other's time. You already know whether this sounds like the kind of top bloke you'd fancy having a pint with. If so, The Sweeney is your film.
Like the ghouls and ghosties confronted by its characters, Insidious overstays its welcome.

Nightcrawler would be worth seeing for Jake Gyllenhaal's performance alone, but it's also a gripping and entertaining deep-dive into a nocturnal world of ruthless opportunism as well as a deliciously caustic satire on moral responsibility.
It's unlikely to become a cultural juggernaut on the level of something like Frozen, but I think it is as enjoyable.
The whole phantasmagorical enterprise is so sweetly confident that it just about gets away with its entirely casual approach to believability.
Displaying a weird lack of memorable or endearing characters, this animated effort feels like a direct-to-video job from the 1990s.
Destined to be appreciated most of all by the filmmakers' friends and family, Here and Now is a modest film with a gentle heart.
Darkly comic and frequently gripping, revenger's tragedy Blue Ruin proves Jeremy Saulnier is a director to watch.
The strength of We Are the Freaks is that it never feels like a cookie-cutter teen movie. It is, as the title suggests, an oddity
Utterly charming, fresh and funny, We Are The Best perfectly captures what it feels like to be young and misunderstood.
Despite some risible moments (often involving computers), this is overall a fresh and funny addition to the Marvel canon.
Too many gags are ill-considered and it's ultimately hard to care whether the engaged couple will make it down the aisle.
An intelligent and artful approach to an underexposed aspect of 20th century culture, the aesthetic successes of Matt Wolf's youth movement doc make you wish more documentaries were made this way.
Frozen' has both showtunes and darkness, but most satisfying is a formula-defying finale that successfully subverts the fairytale status quo.
Effective teen horror with bags of character - think Mean Girls with buckets of blood, only maybe not quite as much of a masterpiece as that would suggest.
An enjoyable, occasionally laughable, and sometimes moving drama, with Emma Thompson on fine brittle form as the quintessentially English Australian who gave the world its most famous nanny.

Thrilling in its own right, but not as thrilling as what we sense is to come, this is a tasty appetizer for the main event with a nice line in sardonic satire and, as ever, a belting lead performance from Jennifer Lawrence.
It's refreshing to see a film about two women that doesn't focus entirely on their love lives, but that's the limit of the cliché-busting; elsewhere, archetypes abound.
Sly, subtle and pitch-perfect ...
The film's quartet of post-slackers are captured as they feel their way around the edges of what they want (and are afraid to ask for) with painful accuracy.
Whatever you make of the book's widely derided author, Ender's Game is one of 2013's more thematically original stories, with a compellingly icy lead performance from Asa Butterfield.
Imagine a Jurassic Park constructed entirely out of whatever foodstuff best satisfies your appetite for a pun.
movie_title: Cloudy with a Chance of Meatballs 2 (2013)

movie_review_blurb: Faulkner fans... need not be up in arms about this version of his Nobel Prize winner.
Enough to make you burn all your Jane Austen.
A hilarious addition to the ever-expanding canvas of the versatile Norwich DJ, Alpha Papa provides solid proof that the bouncebackability of Alan Partridge knows no bounds. Lovely stuff.

A tense and exciting haunted house movie, The Conjuring relies on atmosphere rather than gore to serve up an entertaining slice of ghostie shenanigans with the simple ambition of scaring the bejesus out of viewers.
The gorgeous score and subtle visual craft save this entry in the Ghibli canon from mediocrity. But given what the studio is capable of, it's not everything fans will be hoping for.
'Hummingbird' doesn't always work but wins points for originality.
An amiable enough overview, with the occasional 'say what?' moment.
A short, sweet fondant fancy of a film that recognises when not to outstay its welcome.
Dazzling visual effects and some lively voice work from the comic relief characters just about paper over a disappointingly conventional narrative.
The sparkling highlights make it compulsive viewing, even as the lapses in judgment drive you up the wall.
As a director, Gordon-Levitt demonstrates considerable technical flair through stylistic flourishes and coaxes great performances out of his co-stars.
An interesting idea paired with lacklustre execution makes for a passable rather than thrilling ride.
A modern classic weaving together rich characters, witty satire, thriller elements and political bite. Among the finest films of 2014, look for it to show up on several best-of-the-year lists.
Jennifer Kent's tremendously atmospheric and creepy horror comes highly recommended for those who like complex characterisation and ambiguity with their thrills and chills.
Starts well with dippily exciting action and daft dialogue, but outstays its welcome as it devolves into a deeply daft Ocean's Eleven riff.
Royami is the heart of the film: It is his sincere and artistically principled dream of a musical union between East and West, between Metallica and Kabul Dreams, that fuels the film's engine.
For all its grubbiness, Motel Mist often achieves an undeniable sleazy charm -- it's too silly to feel properly exploitative.
Fleischer-Camp here stakes a claim in conceptually sophisticated documentary territory with a film that, despite frenetic cutting and a lean runtime, rewards contemplation and patience.
A Yellow Bird is fairly convincing and feels authentic, but the film will not readily appeal to audiences who prefer a balance of light and shade.
A brief synopsis... barely hints at the intensity with which the Mexican shocker We Are the Flesh unleashes its joyously demented portrait of humanity.
movie_title: We Are the Flesh (Tenemos la carne) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: British writer-helmer Gareth Tunley makes an auspicious debut with this blend of Lynchian psychodrama with low-budget cop mystery.

Audiences who can be persuaded to look past the perceived barrier of subtitles would likely be charmed by Dasy and Viola, who raise intriguing and timely questions about female bodily autonomy and the question of what is normal.

Raw is realized to a high standard that should break it out beyond specialist distributors and exhibitors, and genre fests that can get in there before release should book it and watch audiences delight in its stylish sense of body horror.
Though pleasant enough to watch, there's something not fully realized about the final product here.
One-man film industry Noel Clarke concludes his 'Hood trilogy with an uneven but respectable final outing for anti-hero Sam Peel.
"Bridget Jones's Baby" is not a comedy for the ages, but it's interesting to see a rom-com starring a middle-aged woman grappling with irrelevance in the workplace.
Ricky Gervais' most enduring creation hits the road for one last attempt at cracking showbiz, in a funny if meandering big-screen adventure.
movie_title: David Brent: Life on the Road (2017)

movie_review_blurb: It's heartening to see Ransome's fiction taking on a new and more independent form, suggesting an ongoing relevance for a series of books that could easily be viewed as too dated for modern children.
Riggan is a gift of a meaty, unflattering role for any middle-aged actor, but feels absolutely tailored to Keaton's strengths, and highly attuned to his career trajectory.
Steve Oram's deeply British feature debut is the kind of mesmerizing cult oddity whose fan base will be limited but passionate.
Takes constant delight in venturing where the vast majority of filmmakers would fear to tread.
The Neon Demon might get the blood pumping temporarily, but it doesn't have staying power.
A wonderful cast are sadly wasted on this screeching melodrama.
movie_title: It's Only the End of the World (Juste la fin du monde) (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Houda Benyamina bursts onto the scene with a punchy, pacy directorial debut, playing as gangster thriller and female buddy movie.
Tunisian-French director Karim Dridi delivers a modest but pacy gangster drama set in the Marseilles projects.
"Suspiria" meets "Ginger Snaps" in a muscular yet elegant campus cannibal horror from bright new talent Julia Ducournau.
Michael O'Shea wears his influences on his sleeve in this downbeat, sporadically engaging slow-burn modern vampire fable.
Cambodian-French helmer Davy Chou's intermittently stylish teen movie lacks narrative momentum but has heart to spare.
Depth is perhaps the stumbling point for "Innocence of Memories." Its ideas are plentiful, but their treatment at times seems to skim the surface.
It's a time-honored style of comedy, accessible to a broad audience, and it works on its own terms, without too many ill-advised attempts at modernization.

Thomas fans with an appetite for endless scenes of hearty romping featuring regrettably song-prone villagers will have little cause for complaint, but commercial potential will be otherwise restricted beyond the film's home turf.

It's all proof that a head-turning first feature can be made for not much more money than a meaty short film nowadays, and, if well done, will act as a far more effective marketing tool for the nascent career of its director.
Yes, there are probably more complex and nuanced ways of tackling this topic, but it's hugely important that a mainstream drama on this subject exists.

The best thing about it is is that it shies away from formula, and the worst is either the finger tattoos, or the fact that it hasn't really come up with much to replace the formula it so carefully and laudably avoids.
Practically every surface in the film screams fetish, and, as in his underrated Stoker, Chan-Wook locates eroticism in some unusual places.

Matthew McConaughey is as compelling as we've come to expect since The Lincoln Lawyer kicked off his 2010s hot streak, as Jeff Nichols ably combines elements of Terence Malick with an all-American rural yarn.
Coming on like Stand by Me meets Son of Rambow, the boys' adventure is essentially dreamy indie-teen wish-fulfilment.
Oblivion's leading man is as dependable as ever. A shame that the film, while pretty, is somewhat ponderous, and ultimately fails to cohere into a narratively satisfying whole.
Marvel's finest heroes finally come together to set a comic book franchise gold standard that will take some beating.
Set to emerge as the year's best horror movie.

A funny, thoroughly enjoyable and oddly subversive film: at a time when CGI reigns in family films and Elizabeth Windsor celebrates a jubilee, here's a film where puppets battle a fiendish regal villain.
A meaty, full-fat, marrow-rich, extra-pulp vision of the nightmare side of motherhood, given realism by a pair of all-too believable performances.
movie_title: We Need to Talk About Kevin (2012)

movie_review_blurb: You don't need to be a fan of - or indeed have more than a passing acquaintance with - the original Tintin comics to enjoy this film.
Weekend has romance to spare, but also takes a look at the cogs turning under the surface of any thoughtful encounter, however brief.
Can't possibly compare to the film it's inspired by, but if you've not seen the 1982 version, you should find it reasonably harmless, albeit with an increasingly daft climax.
Among the year's worst films. The tragedy is funny, the comedy is tragic, and about its only saving grace is that it makes 2010's Valentines Day look almost passable.

A decent, gory horror treat for those who've never watched an Evil Dead movie - while at the same time exhibiting discreet respect for the 1980s incarnations, with plenty of low-key nods to the original for fans.
Goofily gorgeous, heartfelt and endlessly rewatchable, this is the true meaning of escapism - a doorway to another world, a world created to entertain eyes, heart and brain.
If it doesn't quite manage to tap the well of emotion that this type of film aims to access, it's because of problems inherent to the basic pitch, rather than the execution.
A failure, but an interesting failure when you step back and contemplate the project as a whole. Not really anybody's idea of a good time at the cinema that, though, is it?
It's so rare that women get to play fully rounded, three dimensional, flawed human beings, that's it's almost kind of unsettling to realise that's what's going on here.
If you want to see a female action star in the making convincingly kicking the crap out of a succession of photogenic boys, this is the ticket to buy.
Enough already with the famous-equals-feminist school of female icons - it's not enough to simply dress well.
Neither the thriller the trailer suggests, not the feminine, visual poem the poster suggests, this is a film about loss of self that is absolutely clear about its own identity
A good-natured must-see for fans of broad, silly comedies with a little something under the surface too. Bright, breezy and brilliant.
Not terrible.
Thoughtful, well-intentioned and with the odd moment of true emotional resonance, but also overlong and with sometimes rather pat revelations.
There's nothing 'Stranger' about the tides of commercial appeal on which this entry in the franchise floats. Still, it looks nice.
movie_title: Pirates of the Caribbean: On Stranger Tides (2011)

movie_review_blurb: Every frame is a joy to look at, and the three leads very appealing.
The odd amusing line doesn't stop this being pretty bland stuff, but it should keep younger viewers occupied.
The soundtrack's the perfect mixtape, the visuals the perfect day-glo trashpop video - just don't expect too much in the way of boring old depth and meaning.
An extraordinary psychological and sensual immersion in the psychosis of capitalism with a brilliant performance from Robert Pattinson.
Somewhat tedious once the initial novelty of seeing Mel Gibson talk using a beaver puppet has worn off.
I suspect it's supposed to be a heart-warming drama. It left my heart lukewarm, and there's precious little drama.
A very long mess that's embarrassingly devoid of gut level thrills.

Inoffensively didactic and probably of niche appeal in the UK, this is like watching a convincing re-enactment video in history class that's unexpectedly performed by a famous cast of genuine quality.
Possibly it reinforces our awareness that finding any sort of path through life is a pretty overwhelming business, but this is not a terribly radical conclusion.
It may not contain many of the series' most comic, surprising or quotable moments, but it does succeed in bidding adieu in fine fashion to some of this century's most popular fictional characters.
movie_title: Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows - Part 2 (2011)

movie_review_blurb: Cars 2 won't win any new converts, but will sell an awful lot of car toys.
A confident, self-assured comedy with nothing to prove. Fresh, occasionally foul-mouthed, and funny.
A thorny thicket redeemed by its willingness to at least highlight big problems. A film for our times, then.
It's ultimately David Fincher's perfectionist talent for creating a gripping aesthetic that raises this film above your average James Patterson adaptation.
movie_title: The Girl with the Dragon Tattoo (2011)

movie_review_blurb: Hyperactive day-glo fizzy-pop family animation with a heartfelt message about staying true to yourself lurking underneath all the visual fireworks.
The hit rate isn't as high as you'd hope, gag-wise, but Melissa McCarthy and Jason Bateman remain highly likeable screen presences, even when behaving in unlikeable and unlikely ways.
Big silly fun in the Anchorman vein, The Incredible Burt Wonderstone is packed with great gags, recognisable characters and performances from comedians at the top of their game.
You certainly couldn't accuse anyone involved in The Paperboy of playing it safe, and for this reason, Lee Daniels' film is one to file under misjudged must-sees.
It's all entertaining enough, and will surely sell plenty of stuffed toys. But it winds up a fair few rungs below the likes of 'Brave' on the evolutionary ladder.
Decent enough fantasy adventure, but it doesn't especially feel like Tolkien.
Supremely well-intentioned, low-budget British comedy which, with all the will in the world, a likeable cast can't quite power to greatness.
Like a less successful version of The Notebook, this works as an undemanding date movie; just don't expect much more from it.
A funny, thoroughly enjoyable and oddly subversive film.
movie_title: The Pirates! An Adventure With Scientists (2012)

movie_review_blurb: Underrated comic excellence from Sacha Baron Cohen with plenty of sharp satire lacing the broader gross-out gags.
Funny and entertaining, it's not a heavyweight contender, but who wants a heavyweight contender every time?
This is finely-judged filmmaking from a writing and directing talent to watch.
Hit and miss humour with problematic undertones buoyed by an intriguing premise and appealing performances from the film's human cast.
A must for fans of LCD Soundsystem and about fifteen minutes too long for anyone else, this is an entertaining enough exploration of walking away from success and fear of failure.
movie_title: Shut Up and Play the Hits (2012)

movie_review_blurb: A sensitive film that respects the conflict in which it is set rather than using it for cheap thrills.
A certain generosity of spirit is required here, but the performances are excellent and the central premise ... is a solid and amusing one.
movie_title: Seeking a Friend for the End of the World (2012)

movie_review_blurb: More or less serviceable action thriller with some nice ideas for visual set pieces, but did it really have to be as long as it is?
It's doubtful this will win over any outright Anderson sceptics, but ... this is an exciting reaffirmation of talent.
Sexy, perverse and memorable, Stoker lingers in the imagination like an enjoyable hangover.
Essential viewing for understanding different sides of one of the most vital current debates in cinema.
Tolstoy's novel rendered in exquisite Faberge egg form.
An assault on reason, logic and complex characterisation, but in an enjoyable way, like a slightly less camp dramatisation of the Village People's finest ship-based sing-song.
It's Nazis from space. Cult movie fans will basically know what to expect. It's just a shame it couldn't have been a bit better.
If you've the slightest aversion to camp, you should obviously steer clear. But then this film was never for you. It's for the spiritual year-round inhabitants of Dollywood.
Sweet but never sickly ... Electrick Children is real must-see from a bright new talent.
Gangster Squad verges on a parody of hard-boiled noir in the vein of the Scary Movie/Date Movie/Epic Movie films, only with real A-list star power; it's a funny old mixture.
A pumped-up, Hollywood-flavoured neo-Gothic Western delivering knockout performances and raw, corporeal thrills.
A diverting generational three-way dialogue between those barely out of their teens, those in their mid thirties and those well north of fifty.
They don't make 'em like this anymore, except when they do and you remember why they stopped. Daft, but broadly enjoyable if you're in a charitable mood.
Musings on the nature of capitalism wrapped in a very pretty package ... Magic Mike is a film for adventurous audiences of all persuasions.
Complex and problematic in a rather wonderful way, Killing Them Softly has flaws more interesting than some film's perfections.
Rather like a persuasive pick-up artist, I'm not sure Rust & Bone is a film I'd want to spend a second night with, for fear of shattering the emotional illusion.
movie_title: De rouille et d'os (Rust and Bone) (2012)

movie_review_blurb: As the initial joy of being reunited with the colourful assemblage of talent wanes, the audience is left with a film that discernibly lacks the nuance of its predecessor.
movie_title: The Second Best Exotic Marigold Hotel (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Singleton is poorly equipped to handle teenage angst, a fact made far worse by cringe-worthy dialogue and a wooden leading man who proves that he has not yet developed the skills required to carry a film.
Visually stunning and highly entertaining on a number of different levels, Mirror Mirror is the perfect family film for both the young and young at heart.
Despite its faults, the film is worth viewing not only for Malkovich's brilliant performance.

While the film initially requires a modicum of patience as it finds its footing, those who persevere will be rewarded with plenty of chills, thrills and an utterly twisted climax that cements The Canal's status as a memorable yarn.
Although Chemical Peel's shoestring budget is painfully apparent throughout, the film's sub-par production values are in fact the least of its problems.
An unabashedly paint by numbers rom-com, despite its plethora of faults Relative Happiness is rendered watchable by an ingratiatingly offbeat charm and the effortless likeability of its leading lady.
A lazily derivative underdog sporting yarn, 4 Minute Mile treads tired ground.
We started to wonder if ... some unpaid intern had just typed 'Chris Rock,' 'Anthony Hopkins' and 'terrorists' into some Univac-like script machine.
There may be a great movie in this little-known (until recently classified) aspect of WW2, but Windtalkers ain't it.
It made us want to run out and get our very own lobotomy, if only so we could forget having watched that godawful movie.
We have given a name to our pain, and that name is Juwanna Mann.
Basically, it's pretty but dumb.
movie_title: Star Wars: Episode II - Attack of the Clones (2002)

movie_review_blurb: Sweet gentle Jesus, did the screenwriters just do a cut-and-paste of every bad action-movie line in history?
UB equally spoofs and celebrates the more outre aspects of 'black culture' and the dorkier aspects of 'white culture,' even as it points out how inseparable the two are.
Stick with this creepy 1973 masterpiece and you'll be rewarded by a memorable, haunting ending that follows an almost unbearably tense build-up.
The horror relies on special effects so obvious that the scares are compromised.
Quote not available.
Quote not available.
Quote not available.
Quote not available.
The filmmakers wisely decided to let Crocodile Hunter Steve Irwin do what he does best, and fashion a story around him.
You can't expect anything other than an icky art-core sleazefest from director Adrian Lyne.
Was that movie nothing more than a tepid exercise in trotting out a formula that worked five years ago but has since lost its fizz?
How on earth did Disney manage to convince these talented people to get involved in this monumental suck-fest?
Like a fish that's lived too long, Austin Powers in Goldmember has some unnecessary parts and is kinda wrong in places.
Quote not available.
Quote not available.
Even if FearDotCom wasn't a good five years behind the curve, it would still be saddled with a ludicrous script, nonsensical direction and wince-inducing performances.
Maybe it's just us, but Hopkins's interpretation is starting to feel like bad drag.
...a listless tale of sex, stalkers and stupidity for the SAT set.
Determinedly XTrEmE SPoRtz!(tm)...and really, isn't that a little 1994?
We sighed, we swooned, we fell in love. It's really too bad that the movie itself sucks out loud.
Quote not available.
Huston's flawless performance as Sam Dodsworth is the film's greatest joy.
Though it's not easy to watch, Harlem Nights is gorgeous to look at.
While the embarrassment of talent onscreen is a joy to watch, I can't help be overwhelmed and a little saddened thinking how much of that talent went ignored by Hollywood most of the time.
Quote not available.
...The makers of Ballistic: Ecks vs. Sever [take] so many of our favorite things and [make] such a wretched movie out of them.

An air of inevitability punctuates the picture and the lives of the lead characters are under-explored as the directors' focus on tourist ignorance of cultural differences at the expense of any real tension.
Hence, while it works as an antidote to the gritty realism of recent British films, Grow Your Own's twee optimism is sometimes a little too much to digest.

Despite getting off to a good start with an entertaining premise, Waitress ultimately promises more than it delivers, thanks to its less than satisfying final act, a predictably syrupy feel-good finale that the film could well have done without.
Footsoldier doesn't so much pack a punch as leave you feeling violated and more importantly, robs you of two hours of your life you won't get back.
Challenging and thought-provoking.
It's the unlikely chemistry between Binoche and Carell coupled with Carell's impeccable comic timing (watch out for the shower scene) that keeps you glued to the screen.
The film, so desperate in its attempts to shock the viewer through showing the dark side of humanity, is crippled by the fact that the characters are so thinly drawn they have no depth to them.
The sooner Code Name... gets flushed out of cinemas, the better.
Captivating performances from both Vogler and Rottlander whose on-screen chemistry provides the beating heart of Alice In The Cities.
movie_title: Alice in den Städten (Alice in the Cities) (1974)

movie_review_blurb: Razzle Dazzle is a warm hearted yet meaningful affair that sparkles with wit and charm -- and guarantees you'll leave the cinema with a large grin on your face.
movie_title: Razzle Dazzle: A Journey Into Dance (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Shot in a raw, grungy style that lends the film a degree of authenticity, AGN is a riff-roaring experience that rarely hits a bum note.
Bryan Singer returns with a bang, firmly reestablishing his footprint on the series from the opening credits and putting his heroes through hell in the process.
The franchise has finally produced a movie that all will be able to enjoy -- even hard-done-by boyfriends who've been dragged kicking and screaming to see it.
Overall, it delivers on everything Twi-hards will want, but that in itself is this film's failing.
Minor grumbles aside, it's a success, albeit one that will doubtless have parents and boyfriends inwardly groaning at the prospect of being coerced into watching it.
This movie spends too much time on stage, and not enough off.
The rest of the time it's up to Cyrus to keep things light, and her undeniable charisma radiates from the big screen as strongly as it does on the small one.
Disney raised the stakes by turning its hit TV-movie franchise into a feature film -- and the bet has paid off.
Above all, it is a picture to see, without a critics's notebook, as a rare pleasure.

Camp's films are independently produced, use little-known actors, and there's a slightly amateurish quality to them. But Benji: Off the Leash! has a raggy charm, like the dogs, and a solid moral ending.
Oedekerk ... and his team have taken the traditional animation techniques to another level -- creating snowflakes that seem to fall into the audience -- and they pull the viewers into the film.
As fascinating and faceted as its subject.
Grohl has ... created both a fascinating account of the process of analogue recording and a tender tribute to the rock bands of yesteryear.
Buried wrings every last drop of tension from a simple dramatic set-up.
Director Nigel Cole's film is laden with earthy humour and has a massive emotional kick in the final reel.
Roberts is luminous against breathtaking locations including all of Rome's landmarks and colourful, sun-nourished eastern landscapes.
The Town is a well-crafted and vivid portrait of a close-knit community of men with a strict code of silence that condemns those whose speak out to an early grave.
Explosive action sequences collide with polished one-liners and some amusing supporting performances.
The Kid is an accomplished adaptation of Lewis's novel that hammers home Kevin's suffering at the hands of a monstrous matriarch.
Sadly, Dinner For Schmucks isn't a banquet of laughs and the plotting is based around a series of clumsy set pieces.
The screen version of Mr Nice makes his story seem rather pedestrian and the second half of the film becomes repetitive as Howard plays cat and mouse with the authorities.
The Girl Who Played With Fire pulls no punches, and audiences who were on the edge of their seats in the first film will be just as enthralled by this one.
movie_title: The Girl Who Played with Fire (Flickan som lekte med elden) (2010)

movie_review_blurb: The bombardment lasts for almost two hours and by the end of the film, we feel almost as exhausted as the characters.
Some of the performances are wooden, creating repeated moments of unintentional hilarity that cut through the dramatic tension.
Promises tongue-in-cheek thrills but doesn't quite deliver.
One of the main problems here is that there is zero chemistry between the two leads -- and we're not given any real reason to root for them to get together.
It may be more than two decades since Michael Douglas won an Oscar as scheming Wall Street trader Gordon Gekko, but the character's mantra of "Greed is good" rings as loud as ever.
A frenetic 94 minutes of laughter, thrills and heart-warming sentiment.
Lacks much of the sense of fun that made the original film a blast.
movie_title: Cats & Dogs: The Revenge of Kitty Galore (2010)

movie_review_blurb: The Social Network is technically flawless, powered by Fincher's dazzling direction...
A fast-paced romp that severs ties to realism early on and once we suspend our disbelief and put our brains into neutral, the film is a lot of fun.

From its droll opening voiceover Will Gluck's film has us in the palm of its hand, rooting for an unconventional heroine who finds the silver lining in a huge, dark cloud over a pivotal year at high school.
Alas, Due Date takes a simple premise and goes nowhere with it as the two lead characters travel thousands of miles on a journey of self-discovery.
Another beautifully observed portrait of modern life from Mike Leigh.
You Again may have some very experienced faces in the cast, but the end product still turns out to be disappointingly cliched and trite.
Monsters is a brilliantly executed thriller which puts multi-million dollar blockbusters to shame.
The film appropriates elements from Shrek and The Incredibles and produces an entertaining hybrid that should have parents chuckling with glee.
Luckily Depp and Jolie are an attractive central pairing who smoulder with on-screen chemistry while the rest of the film crumbles around them.
The Voyage Of The Dawn Treader is the most crudely constructed of the films, loosely stitching together the set pieces with comical altercations between Eustace and his courageous cousins.
movie_title: The Chronicles of Narnia: The Voyage of the Dawn Treader (2010)

movie_review_blurb: Any sense of joy, which coursed through Meet The Parents and Meet The Fockers, has completely evaporated.
Black can barely keep a straight face as he gambols from one digital effects sequence to the next.
A visual tour-de-force, complemented by Franco's fearless performance, that holds us spellbound...
If your idea of cinema heaven is plenty of gun fights and car chases then by and large that's what Knight and Day does.
With fellow rom-com queen Sandra Bullock taking up Oscar-winning serious acting, it's nice to know Aniston is not giving up her crown anytime soon.
Noisy, overblown, lacking substance, but still likeable.

By turns touching and funny, The Boys Are Back is a tribute to the resilience of the human spirit and a reminder there is no instruction manual for good parenting. Sometimes you just have to muddle through.
Brothers is distinguished by emotionally raw performances and an escalating tension.
Sidibe deserves an Oscar nomination for her compelling performance, while even more impressive is Mo'Nique's fearless embodiment of Mary.
movie_title: Precious: Based on the Novel Push by Sapphire (2009)

movie_review_blurb: The film version condenses six episodes of edge-of-seat suspense into an engrossing two hours.
Another superb humanist drama from Eastwood.
Some of the plot strands are hopelessly contrived and characters could have been cut entirely.
Crafted with the same attention to detail that Ford brings to his menswear collections, A Single Man is a deeply moving portrait of love and death, anchored by Firth's fearless central turn.
Not all that much happens in Michael Hoffman's The Last Station. But what doesn't happen, happens beautifully.

Ironically, it's Travolta's voracious, scenery-chewing and wide-eyed ravings which turn out to be the guilty pleasure of From Paris With Love, an otherwise dumb action adventure that clumsily pilfers scenes from the Bourne trilogy.
Promoting a stereotypical image of rural Ireland which would make Father Ted roll his eyes in disbelief, Leap Year is a sappy road movie and frankly implausible comedy.
The visuals are stunning, as you would expect, but characterisation is weak, and Depp's turn is one bout of lunacy too far.
It is not Scorsese's finest offering by a long way, leaving us disoriented but ultimately unfulfilled as the cops get their answers.
Sweet, sexy and at times hilarious.
The King's Speech is an impeccably crafted chapter from recent British history that charts a remarkable and unlikely friendship between two men from opposite sides of the class divide.
The Blind Side wears its heart on its shoulder padding for the entire 128 minutes and eventually, the wholesomeness of the characters, pulling together for a common cause, wins us over.
Nanny McPhee is back -- and she still knows best.
The plot ambles and Gervais and Merchant can't resist neatly tying up every loose end in a manner which strains credibility. Their dramatic crescendo is a mother pouring a cup of tea.
A routine thriller elevated by Polanski's direction and an A-list cast, who are never stretched.
Moore looks fabulous in a role that plays to her strengths as a feisty, independent woman, and she generates on-screen heat with Duchovny to make the conventional happy ending easier to swallow.
The pair have impeccable comic timing, and an easy rapport which helps create a wholly believable core to what is essentially a totally outlandish plot.
After a confident build-up, the ending feels like an anti-climax.
Newell orchestrates the set pieces with energy and he confidently melds live action elements with digital trickery.
movie_title: Prince of Persia: The Sands of Time (2010)

movie_review_blurb: The Losers is a rollicking romp, and set pieces are breathlessly orchestrated, culminating in an overblown showdown at the dockyards, and the banter is riddled with snappy one-liners.
You can have too much of a good thing and we have our fill of Aldous's sexist outbursts well before the end of the first hour.
Whatever Works works.
Heartbreaker boasts stunning locations, a snappy script and bubbling soundtrack, merged together in an irresistible romp that proves the search for true love is fraught with misunderstandings.
Shrek Forever After brings the long-running saga to a lively close, reminding each of the characters about the love and friendship which bind them together.
Toy Story 3 surpasses the 1995 original and its 1999 sequel for thrills, spills and laughs, delivering the most satisfying journey of the trilogy.
Inception is elegantly realised. DiCaprio powerfully embodies a tortured soul while Gordon-Levitt has all the fun in the best action sequence.
It's Chan's best performance in years and Smith is a likeable leading man.
The Green Hornet puts the masked avenger at the centre of a flimsy, illogical plot and series of headache-inducing action sequences that strain the eyes in 3D.
Every time Hardwicke's film threatens to veer into dark, unsettling territory, it's sweetened with sickly sweet romance.
How Do You Know is a slight and predictable tale of modern day love, padded with subplots about father-son bonding and undeclared love.
Sadly, despite all those comedians the movie falls short on laughs.
Love, loss, courage, hope and humour -- Deathly Hallows offers them all in what proves a worthy finale to the Potter saga.
movie_title: Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows - Part 2 (2011)

movie_review_blurb: The plot is ... flimsy and the three screenwriters struggle to bring the murderous mayhem to a satisfying conclusion.
Visuals look spectacular and action sequences take full advantage of the 3D format so you feel like you are burning rubber down winding roads at dizzying speed.
Oh dear, oh dear. Rarely has a film title been more fitting than this disappointing cinematic outing based on the mischievous character created by author Francesca Simon.
Though Zookeeper doesn't really cast any lingering animal magic, it has enough laughs to keep family audiences engaged during the summer holidays.
The movie proves a solid if not superb opening salvo for the weakling-turned-super soldier.
A saccharine family-oriented comedy, which hammers home the central message about parental responsibility and love triumphing over adversity with all the tenderness of a nasty case of frostbite.
Super 8 is a delightful nostalgia trip, recalling a bygone era when young protagonists embarked on amazing journeys and emerged from the melee with barely a scratch or bruise.
Takes advantage of the latest technological wizardry to deliver a thrilling action adventure that doesn't skimp on heartbreaking emotion.
movie_title: Rise of the Planet of the Apes (2011)

movie_review_blurb: Recycles the fish-out-of-water plot of Alvin and the Chipmunks and doesn't have any original ideas about what to do with the tiny characters once they are at large among us.

It does actually seem to work, giving audiences a healthy number of action pieces and a solid storyline that isn't as bonkers as it looks on paper - if you're willing to suspend a massive dollop of belief that is.
If you're a fan of the show then you're going to find a lot to enjoy on their overseas adventure.
Conviction is a remarkable true story that provides Swank with a meaty central role that wrings tears and fury in equal measure.
Approached for what it is - a series of over-the-top gruesome death scenes pieced together by an implausible plot - this might be the best Final Destination yet.
Elegantly adapted for the screen by Moira Buffini, Jane Eyre condenses the source novel into two hours of yearning and regret.
Friends With Benefits almost gets away with the double standards because Justin Timberlake and Mila Kunis are such an attractive pairing.
The plot glides effortlessly from conflict to resolution, convincing us you can have your cake and eat it.
movie_title: I Don't Know How She Does It (2011)

movie_review_blurb: Tinker, Tailor, Soldier, Spy is intelligent filmmaking of the highest calibre, distinguished by tour de force performances from the predominantly British cast.
A sophisticated romantic comedy boasting pithy dialogue and exemplary performances from a cast which explores the many winding paths to true love.
The tension is agonising... then rubber burns, the engine revs and we hold on tight. For the next 90 minutes, we don't let go.
The Debt cranks up the tension and elegantly conceals plot twists by cutting back and forth between events in 1966 and 1997.
After this second assignment, Johnny's licence to thrill has been revoked.
Daldry draws a memorable and believable performance from the youngster, who had never acted before but who has to carry the bulk of the film's narrative on his slender shoulders.
An artfully composed portrait of intellectual one-upmanship.
Lasse Hallstrom's beautifully-shot but at times cloyingly sentimental rom-com.
It's remarkable for a first-time feature film director to keep a tight rein on all these elements and meld them with such dynamism and style.
Zombieland is an hilarious jaunt through a futuristic America ravaged by a contagion that has changed all but a lucky few into flesh-chomping predators.
Despite everything, it's an able adaptation capturing the spirit of the original novel, which fans will still enjoy.
Larry Crowne is an uplifting cinematic trifle garnished with an unwavering belief that it's never too late to embrace life.
We're very happy to fall in love with Malick's opus.
The Beaver sensitively deals with themes of mental illness, suicide and self-belief, plumbing some very dark nooks of the human psyche.
Disney's delightful animated reworking of the Rapunzel fairytale marries a hilarious script with dazzling and colourful visuals.
An incredible story of triumph against adversity in and out of the boxing ring.
Brighton Rock lacks the intensity and menace of the 1947 film version, but Joffe shows promise behind the camera.

Concert footage attests to Bieber's ability to sing live including U Smile with backing from Boyz II Men, a duet of Overboard with Miley Cyrus, a remix of Somebody To Love featuring Usher and the infuriatingly catchy Baby.
Next to Shaun of the Dead and Hot Fuzz, Paul does feel flat, although Pegg and Frost paper over the cracks with nods and winks to classic fantasy and sci-fi films.
Drive Angry 3D is a hoot, as long as you down-shift your brain into neutral and submit to the endless barrage of obscenities and gratuitous violence.
Thankfully, this film is blessed with director Reitman and well-judged performances from Natalie Portman and Ashton Kutcher, who generate smouldering on-screen chemistry.
The Adjustment Bureau is smartly scripted and slickly directed, and is anchored by yet another compelling performance from the ever reliable Matt Damon.
Fair Game is a gripping snapshot of the events leading up to the war in Iraq and the subsequent fallout for Valerie, Joe and their family.
Hall Pass boasts a couple of big laughs. For the most part though, our response to the script is weak smiles.
Felicity Jones confirms her reputation as one of our brightest talents in this comedy about a young woman's struggle to vanquish her inner demons.
An at times gripping, at times bludgeoning tale of one man's search for truth and retribution.
A ridiculously entertaining thrill-ride that jettisons dialogue and characterisation to deliver two-and-a-half hours of testosterone-fuelled carnage.

Source Code doesn't become too bogged down in the science behind the thrills, and while Colter is destined to repeat the same journey down the line, each visit is sufficiently different to hold our attention.
Snyder and co-writer Steve Shibuya present fire-breathing dragons, samurais and zombie soldiers, but they also starve our brains with a flimsy, nonsensical tale of reality versus fantasy.
Our affection for Winnie The Pooh hasn't diminished with time and this delightful animated feature ensures the residents of Hundred Acre Wood will continue to enchant.
A nice idea poorly executed, underpinned by a script with too few laughs and an unsympathetic heroine.
More entertaining than its lacklustre predecessor but has the feel of a straight-to-DVD film.
movie_title: Diary of a Wimpy Kid 2: Rodrick Rules (2011)

movie_review_blurb: A tasteless, preposterous and ultimately pointless tale of east meets west which lurches from one improbable set piece to the next including the bizarre concealment of a dead body and a high-speed car chase.
The denouement strains credibility, relying on a character showing restraint when they've merrily pulled the trigger for the rest of the film.
Wells's fast-paced film mixes action, comedy and some heart-tugging emotion, delivering out of this world thrills to audiences of all ages.
Cornish plays loose and fast with conventions of the genre and he doesn't think twice about sacrificing some of his young protagonists to the creatures to underline the clear and present danger.
The film runs aground courtesy of Marshall's plodding direction and a lifeless script.
movie_title: Pirates of the Caribbean: On Stranger Tides (2011)

movie_review_blurb: Water For Elephants casts a spell with its arresting visuals and the cast looks ravishing through a soft-focus lens.
Hanna sits between two audiences - arthouse and multiplex - and will disappoint both.
Thor's digital trickery and pyrotechnics doesn't appear to faze Branagh, who balances the thrills of a summer blockbuster with tender romance and broad comedy.
Admittedly, some episodes strain credibility, but we are resolutely behind the morally flawed protagonists every stumble of the way.
Undermines its central message about substance over style by sacrificing characterisation for glossy visuals.
Arthur boasts some nice moments, most of them involving Mirren and Brand whose on screen rapport sustains interest through the 110 minute running time.
Sheen internalises his character's anguish and we see sadness welling up in Tom's eyes, underscored with occasional moments of humour.
A little self-indulgent at times, but Salome Richard is captivating in the lead.
An important reminder of why we need conflict journalists - and the dangers they face.
Wholly forgettable.
movie_title: Up for Love (Un homme à la hauteur) (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Compelling and at times heartbreaking.
Warning: Hijinks really don't ensue.
